messages: 3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (23:06): hey guys, i've spent a few days trying to solve this issue and the ppl in #css/#html5 are stuck too.. maybe some html/css genius in here can do it: http://www.pastie.org/private/xo1w15miulgzf3ho9oya
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (23:06): basically i just need the sub menu lower and left aligned to the main menu regardless of which main menu LI the sub menu UL is attached to
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (23:08): 3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d, wrong channel
3c6e0b8a9c15224a8228b9a98ca1531d (23:08): only douches in here?
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (23:08): today's youth
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:08): also yesterday's youth and tomorrow's youth
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:09): the only thing special about today's youth is they happen to be the ones you'll see ... today
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (23:10): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6, it was just an empty "get off my lawn" phrase. it was entirely meaningless :>
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:11): don't worry, i'm sitting on the porch shaking my fist at those damned kids too :P
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:12): so I'm still awake and apparently Ms2ger needs not be summoned to IRC for regenerating the spec
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:12): http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/domcore/raw-file/tip/Overview.html#events
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:15): seems sort of odd that "propagation flag" and "immediate propagation flag" seem more like "stop propagation flag" ... as if the values are reversed
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:16): hmm yeah
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:16): I wanted to shorten their length but that does not make it clearer indeed
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:17): just flip the booleans? maybe given their purpose that would be odd (since they would be inverted from "canceled flag")
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:18): no I am adding stop back in
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:19): you want to be in the list of acknowledgments as &quot 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6" or some other name?
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:19): The timeStamp attribute must be useless.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:20): Glenn Maynard
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:20): aha
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:21): i've wished the timeStamp attribute worked in the past ... when doing things like emulating double-clicks from mouse (actually, touch) events
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:21): guess it's just too far outside of browser event models to be able to do that reasonably
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:24): I think the way it works in Gecko enables that
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:24): not really sure how to define it yet
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:24): I wouldn't mind dropping it or having it always return 0 like in Opera, but that's not really the most useful

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:37): "Because createEvent() is located on the Document object it cannot be used by Web Workers." hmm ... although it clearly amtters less in workers (without the DOM, the more complex uses of events go away anyway), it does seem like an odd missing piece, given that events are still used; no particular use cases come to mind off-hand, though (possibly just due to not having used workers in complex enough ways yet)
07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a (23:38): Now that WHATWG HTML is versionless, the W3C copy is the only thing that can be referred to as "HTML5", ending confusion.
07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a (23:38): And making the relationship between the two very clear.
07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a (23:40): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: It is sad that your blog don't have comments.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:41): I saw your tweet... I don't really want to have to maintain such discussions anymore.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:42): But this is the web, you do not have to be constrained with what I am offering on my site ;)
07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a (23:43): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: Except that as it happened, IE9 went RC around that time.
07c42ad49ef5c29784dce33083aec77a (23:48): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: To summarize: IE stagnated for five years, then it took another five years for it to finally implement XHTML!
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:48): am I the only person that keeps trying to define javascript functions as "var func() { }"? it's an instinct I just can't override, heh
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:57): "The list of event listeners can be manipulated while event listeners are being run." a bit vague--will the particulars of that be specified?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:58): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6, it's just a statement of fact
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:58): addEventListener and removeEventListener already define how the list is manipulated
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:58): the rest is just going through a live list

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:00): well, it seems that event handlers added during dispatch aren't being called, but ones removed also aren't (that is, removals during invocation are honored, but additions aren't) ... trying to see if that behavior is defined by the spec
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:01): that is not
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:03): hmm yeah

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:03): it could be: define step 4 of invocation as operating on a copy of the event handler list, and have removeEventListener mark the event listener unused (for example, set its name to null, so 4.3 always terminates)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:05): you can dispatch empty string events but yeah, something like that might work
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:06): that would also avoid any ambiguity if, for example, an event handler is removed from the list then re-added in the same event
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:08): it would not be triggered then right?
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:08): since logically it's a new listener
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:08): so for nodes this is per "current target" I assume?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:09): that is, a current target can manipulate the listeners for the next current target as pleased
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:09): right ... i havn't checked that part of browser behavior though
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:12): http://pastebin.com/kzscSk01 clicking text alerts in Opera but not FF3.6 or Chrome
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:14): http://pastebin.com/ZTRw2iga same results when removing and adding in the same handler
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:14): so Opera has the DOM3Events behavior of having a static copy
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:15): whoa, so adding it again marks it "used" or some such?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:15): in Gecko/WebKit
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:15): hmm, I should try sleeping again and maybe play with IEs implementation tomorrow
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:16): i imagine that removing it marks the listener as "dead", and adding it later adds an entirely new listener
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:16): oh right, see, I'm tired

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:16): which was what I was going for above with the notion of clearing "name" (which was just a shorthand hack, of course, should be a named property or something in a spec)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:18): fun stuff
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:21): re: manipulating listeners the next ancestor target, yes in all of those browsers: http://pastebin.com/NEdKDMHT
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:21): thanks man
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:22): I wonder if Opera has any bugs filed against it for having a completely static list
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:22): and what IE does
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:23): not having to add a "dead flag" might be nice
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:23): did you do the work boiling down the dispatch/invocation rules? because that's pretty well done
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:23): anyway, sleep
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:23): yeah, you can see how i went about it here: https://bitbucket.org/ms2ger/web-dom-core
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:24): later, go to sleep before you get dragged into something else, that's what IRC does :P
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:24): heh :)
